3FE7062221DA4D078758256E6120DDAF.description: apply mathematical skills correctly in foodpreparation tasks (e.g., convert between imperial and metric measurements; calculate yield changes)

47253DD190164D5C8FE1F6797E32F0F2.description: demonstrate an understanding of common terms used in food preparation (e.g., names of utensils and techniques)

96D1F16EA7EF4FA78A917FC47CBF7BA5.description: demonstrate the ability to follow a recipe

8404B6AFDACE4EBE856F50046655166E.description: demonstrate an understanding of the information found on Canadian food labels and on labels of foods from other countries

E5F5C97806D6493FA3DD874A63214656.description: Kitchen Literacy and Numeracy: demonstrate the literacy and numeracy skills required in food preparation.

DE84E06AF7F1450EBF5133DAFAAD1591.description: plan and prepare a variety of food items from various countries/cultures using culturally specific ingredients and techniques

A37CC494935942F68747C3C8DDD64888.description: demonstrate an understanding of meal customs and table-setting practices in a variety of cultures (e.g., sitting on the floor on a rug in northern Africa; sitting on tatami [mats] for a traditional Japanese meal; setting the table with many utensils for a formal European meal)

E9DB70F9FE9B4CE98ABAE367860C9A29.description: demonstrate the ability to manage time effectively in food preparation

03D2B5A11BF5472BB6EFB9E6BB9F06EC.description: demonstrate the correct use of foodpreparation techniques (e.g., stirring, beating, whipping, chopping, broiling, frying)

CE066AF414864394A35BBFB0811E8B46.description: demonstrate the ability to measure quantities accurately (e.g., use different strategies for measuring wet and dry ingredients; level off excess amounts; measure liquids at eye level)

3A6070FAED5E43E597DA56EA102D9B89.description: demonstrate the ability to adapt recipes from other countries/cultures by substituting equipment that is readily available (e.g., use a frying pan instead of a wok; use a standard oven instead of a clay oven; use a Dutch oven or slow cooker instead of a tajine)

66BA93FAC528469696CD0BEF523FB853.description: demonstrate the ability to safely use, maintain, clean, and store tools and equipment used in food preparation

B01CCFC87C43458C9AFB4654556185CD.description: identify the tools and equipment used for preparing, serving, and eating foods from a variety of cultures (e.g., wok, tajine, barbeque, smoker, clay oven, bamboo steamer, chopsticks, mortar and pestle, skewer)

BCC0C2CED48B496C93108DCB7F6395AF.description: Food Preparation: demonstrate skills used in food preparation in various countries/cultures;

D60077ACB07347A0826472F865B359C9.description: follow appropriate protocols to ensure food safety (e.g., cook foods to recommended temperatures; keep hot foods hot and cold foods cold; store food appropriately; wipe tops of cans before opening; check "best-before" dates; demonstrate awareness of common allergenic ingredients)

4231FE95C89946F1A47F54001E0DE29B.description: use safe food-handling practices to prevent cross-contamination by pathogens, parasites, and allergens in the food-preparation area (e.g., wash fresh produce; sanitize cutting boards after contact with meat products; sanitize implements that come into contact with allergens when preparing food for or with people with known allergies; sanitize work surfaces; replace and/or sanitize sponges or cloths frequently; use proper clean-up procedures)

A46DD20F34FA4C1E864A1268335EBE43.description: use appropriate personal hygiene practices to prevent contamination of food (e.g., wash hands frequently; cover a cough or sneeze in their sleeve; use gloves to cover cuts or wounds; tie hair back)

70297563911542D184408FCCDBF9FA8E.description: describe the causes and symptoms of foodborne illnesses (e.g., E. coli poisoning, botulism poisoning, Clostridium perfringens poisoning, salmonellosis, listeriosis) and techniques for preventing these illnesses

63C8F7D903994934B9A99FCCD142C34A.description: Food Safety: demonstrate an understanding of practices that ensure or enhance food safety;

72C5EC34D9AD4A59A4ECA270BC96D907.description: demonstrate an understanding of appropriate emergency responses to common accidents associated with food preparation (e.g., cuts, burns, scalds, fires)

F541AA2139FB45BC99EBCF0570FDF593.description: demonstrate an understanding of safe practices within the food-preparation area (e.g., safely handle hot foods; prevent spatters, scalds, and cuts; wipe up spills immediately)

A948056D50B44B709200FAE7555AA6FE.description: describe common accidents that can occur in the kitchen (e.g., cuts, burns, fires, falls, poisoning, electric shocks)

C4F5443FC0644081A57EFDA9E5B56D04.description: Kitchen Safety: demonstrate an understanding of practices that ensure or enhance kitchen safety;

34D20869533B4F2886430ED7A6B548CD.description: plan and prepare a food item or items using herbs and spices typical of the cuisine of a particular country/culture

5ADAEDD8D44E434BA897D38E2AFD10C9.description: describe characteristic flavours and aromas of the cuisines of various cultures

C13708E14451496AA4B079A0AD672DA9.description: identify the sources and common uses of herbs and spices in the cuisines of various countries/cultures

72B2A11BC4F84A918673E192A065D77B.description: Flavours of the World: demonstrate an understanding of the characteristic flavours, aromas, herbs, and spices associated with the cuisines of various countries/cultures.

E96C9D99895D438FB1C57FAFF6518018.description: plan and prepare a food item or items using ingredients from a variety of countries/cultures

1A73DA2C11B44A3C8D24E84DF82334D3.description: identify different ways in which certain food sources are used around the world (e.g., rice: noodles, rice paper, rice pudding, risotto; corn/maize: flour, tortillas, polenta, oil; chickpeas: hummus, chana masala, flour, dahl; wheat: flour, bannock, pasta, cereal, breads such as pita, naan, focaccia, challah)

4ED4E6AC73A7424989AE0D1EEAE9059F.description: identify foods that are regularly eaten as a dominant part of the diet in different parts of the world (e.g., grains/cereals such as rice, wheat, maize/corn, millet, sorghum; roots and tubers such as potatoes, cassava, yams, taro; animal products such as meat, milk, eggs, cheese, fish)

B6B709E2D4A54651B448C50E5A7B32CB.description: identify the origins of various foods eaten in Canada (e.g., potatoes, breads, corn, rice, bananas, tofu, various cheeses, various herbs and spices)

C46A283782D440FBB3734FC9BD427335.description: Sources of Foods: demonstrate an understanding of the sources of foods eaten in Canada and in various other countries/cultures;

EA11C11CEB034DBAA827259B7B77B6DA.description: describe ways in which food-acquisition practices vary among people who live in rural and urban environments (e.g., in rural areas, people may grow some of their own food, keep poultry for eggs and/or meat, hunt for seasonal game; in urban areas, people have access to large grocery stores and may have access to food products from a variety of cultures, local farmers' markets, and community gardens)

7CA40E57092548829F114E3C3C1118F2.description: identify foods that are naturally found or produced in particular countries and regions of the world (e.g., rice in the Far East, maize/corn in Central America, fish/seafood in Spain and Portugal, olives in Mediterranean countries)

1A9E57E9546F4C8CBCD446500EFC8AF3.description: explain the relationship between geography and the foods naturally found or produced in various countries or regions (e.g., tropical and citrus fruits in countries with consistently warm climates, fish/seafood in coastal areas, food products from grazing animals in grassland areas)

2B7B23FD11E14D49AC00A0978020B222.description: explain how overhunting and overfishing, as well as the reduction or elimination of natural habitats, have affected the availability of foods found in different regions of Canada

6B0ED8AB3DDB4EA19C741FE5CEC775B9.description: explain the relationship between geography and the foods naturally found or produced in Canada (e.g., the influence on food production of land formations, rainfall, the location of fertile farmland or temperate climates)

21A93D3CA9C74DF883B9520A952115E7.description: identify foods naturally found or produced in the different regions of Canada (e.g., salmon on the west coast, beef and bison on the prairies, Saskatoon berries on the prairies, cranberries in Ontario, grapes in southern Ontario, fish/seafood in the Atlantic provinces, seal and whale in the far north)

7A85BEEE90C04E16A31BC804CF5DD12C.description: Food Availability: demonstrate an understanding of the relationship between geography and the foods naturally found and/or produced in Canada and in various other countries;

8C8E001BEBBC4C8E9ACAE0FDB2FA43A0.description: describe some cultural variations in dining etiquette (e.g., seating arrangements, order and use of utensils, appropriate sounds while eating)

285AF28A176D41208E2CD5A19D5AD964.description: describe some cultural variations in daily eating patterns (e.g., time of day for meals, number of meals per day, timing and typical content of the main meal of the day)

C61476E3A0B44849A54976558693029C.description: describe some food-production and foodacquisition practices in Canada and in a variety of other countries/cultures (e.g., cultivation on small family farms, organic farming practices, large monoculture farms, the use of chemicals and genetically modified seeds/plants, the role of hunting and fishing, growing cash crops, growing for local

C32A26F4EF5744D09EFE172CF987ED9D.description: identify where in their local community foods from various cultures can be acquired (e.g., international aisles at grocery stores, the school cafeteria, restaurants, community events, culture-specific grocery markets)

0CCDC411E2D44F148124AA4D99C38C88.description: identify foods from other cultures that have become common in Canada (e.g., samosas, sushi, pizza, fried rice, pita, nachos, tortillas, dhal, bannock)

8072DD2860784A42BB09F0E7D336726B.description: Culture and Food Habits: demonstrate an understanding of the influence of culture on how people obtain, prepare, serve, and consume food.

C2FD5A8A70E64529BD33236AB96326F4.description: compare recommendations in Canada's Food Guide with those in food guidelines from other countries (e.g., Dietary Guidelines for Americans, Mediterranean Food Guide, Chinese Food Guide)

8450FB9CA17842878CAC0C9E6471AD63.description: compare recommendations in Canada's Food Guide with those in the First Nations, Inuit, and Métis Food Guide

628EA03A56DD4E5B9984B5300981BC3D.description: identify key recommendations in Canada's Food Guide (e.g., choose lower-fat milk products; have vegetables and fruit more often than juice)

9FA7852EBFB94E1E8E4FC097C290DDB1.description: plan and prepare a food item or items associated with a special occasion of their own or another culture or country

07D28F3207B840F999F5CA558E201E8E.description: describe some technological innovations that make local and imported foods available to Canadians in all seasons (e.g., refrigerated trucks, freeze drying, deep freezing, cold storage, greenhouse food production)

AD756096B90F482582837450CB03F681.description: identify specific foods that are served for special occasions in Canada and other countries (e.g., for national holidays, cultural and religious celebrations, weddings, harvest celebrations)

7E1DDA6B323F442792057F1B7038F631.description: describe how various factors (e.g., geography, religion, economics, culture, environment, values) influence personal food choices

EBA2AF0D06114A9DB66E02494C0F9B58.description: Food Choices: demonstrate an understanding of the factors that influence food choices, with reference to a variety of cultures;

D9FD8568F29148BCA602B05E260D1BD1.description: demonstrate an understanding of the general research process by reflecting on and evaluating their own research, inquiry, and communication skills

188273BFDA314EF5ABFA7EF8D639BB24.description: clearly communicate the results of their inquiries (e.g., write clearly, organize ideas logically, use language conventions properly), and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources (e.g., generate a reference list in APA style)

2C0E054DFF644BA18DD4D6FD3489C30E.description: use terms relating to food and culture correctly (e.g., staple foods, etiquette, eating patterns, tajine, wok, cuisine)

4B7C6FD779E34C4C8A03BC12DA79B6FE.description: use an appropriate format (e.g., brochure, flyer, poster, multimedia presentation) to communicate the results of their research and inquiry effectively for a specific audience and purpose

81A2B7E7E31C4BCCAEF3EEFAA2C52BF4.description: synthesize findings and formulate conclusions (e.g., weigh and connect information to determine the answer to their research question)

3179F6CA512B41089E51B379FFACB014.description: demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research

2A002DCFC1D74517AB84C0E4EEA54385.description: analyse and interpret research information (e.g., compare information from different sources; identify gaps in information that necessitate further research)

63D55D8CFFFC46228A7001E50F585C33.description: record and organize information and key ideas using a variety of formats (e.g., notes, graphic organizers, audio/visual/digital records)

D0E5004858DB42E68AE5F020F0206327.description: assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values and bias, voice)

8CAF3AE415E34399835D2EE4D9001AAC.description: Processing Information: assess, record, analyse, and synthesize information gathered through research and inquiry;

C0A09F0786A74D14A04F801206856237.description: locate and select information relevant to their investigations from a variety of primary sources (e.g., interviews, surveys, questionnaires, observations) and/or secondary sources (e.g., textbooks, advertisements, brochures, newspaper and magazine articles, cookbooks, recipe websites)

81EBB76BC62648ED9449F75BA08486B3.description: create appropriate research plans to investigate their selected topics (e.g., outline purpose and method; identify sources of information), ensuring that their plans follow guidelines for ethical research

FE6E80871D27418EAF17679ADA4D1156.description: Investigating: create research plans, and locate and select information relevant to their chosen topics, using appropriate social science research and inquiry methods;

82505363460D4DC88C304C2E8226281D.description: formulate effective questions to guide their research and inquiry

2CB0CAF4C0C84B4B83C6C6430BBD6EC0.description: identify key concepts (e.g., through discussion, brainstorming, use of visual organizers) related to their selected topics

2DC2E84BF35F4DBFB0EAE3F77C898FF3.description: explore a variety of topics related to food and culture (e.g., food guidelines from around the world, herbs and spices used in different cuisines) to identify topics for research and inquiry

9236C46CF3B14E8CAA62CC69D38F127D.description: Exploring: explore topics related to food and culture, and formulate questions to guide their research;
